title: FLARE: Feed-forward Geometry, Appearance and Camera Estimation from Uncalibrated Sparse Views
author: Shangzhan Zhang (Zhejiang University), Jianyuan Wang (University of Oxford), Yinghao Xu (Ant Group), Nan Xue (Ant Group), Christian Rupprecht (University of Oxford), Xiaowei Zhou (Zhejiang University), Yujun Shen (Ant Group), Gordon Wetzstein (Stanford University)
relevance_why: The paper presents a novel approach to camera pose estimation and geometry reconstruction that may provide insights and inspiration for applications in audio-visual setups, particularly in environments where synchronizing visual and audio data is crucial.
background: The task involves reconstructing 3D scenes and estimating camera poses using minimal uncalibrated images, improving efficiency and accuracy in visual recognition systems.
contribution: FLARE introduces a cascaded learning paradigm for estimating camera poses, geometry, and appearance from sparse-view images, achieving state-of-the-art performance in less than 0.5 seconds.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods typically relied on handcrafted feature matching and optimization stages, which struggled with sparse views.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by using feed-forward learning and a transformer-based architecture, allowing for real-time inference and better handling of challenging scenes.

key_innovation: It uniquely integrates camera pose estimation with geometry learning in a cascaded manner, enabling faster and more accurate 3D reconstruction from minimal input images.
real_world_impact: This approach can significantly enhance applications in robotics and augmented reality, allowing for quicker scene understanding in dynamic environments with limited visual data.
limitations: The method struggles with thin structures and out-of-distribution camera trajectories.

new_terms.cascaded learning paradigm: **Cascaded learning paradigm** refers to a stepwise approach in which one task is performed after another, using outputs from the previous task as inputs for the next, effectively simplifying the learning problem.
new_terms.Gaussian Splatting: **Gaussian Splatting** is a technique used to represent surfaces in 3D space through Gaussian distributions, allowing for efficient rendering and manipulation of complex shapes.

open_sourcing: The project page and code can be found at: https://zhanghe3z.github.io/FLARE/
